title: Psalms Chapter 14 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 14 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 14 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 14.

questions.question: According to Psalms 14:1, what has the fool said in his heart?
options: There is no God
God is everywhere
God is love
God is just
questions.correctAnswer: There is no God
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:1 states, 'The fool hath said in his heart, There is no God.'

questions.question: In Psalms 14:2, from where did the LORD look down upon the children of men?
options: From heaven
From the temple
From the mountains
From the earth
questions.correctAnswer: From heaven
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:2 says, 'The LORD looked down from heaven upon the children of men.'

questions.question: What is described as being done by all according to Psalms 14:3?
options: They are all gone aside
They all do good
They all pray
They all sing praises
questions.correctAnswer: They are all gone aside
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:3 states, 'They are all gone aside, they are all together become filthy.'

questions.question: Who are described as having no knowledge in Psalms 14:4?
options: Workers of iniquity
Righteous men
The priests
The prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Workers of iniquity
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:4 asks, 'Have all the workers of iniquity no knowledge?'

questions.question: According to Psalms 14:5, where is God present?
options: In the generation of the righteous
In the temple only
Only in heaven
Among the sinners
questions.correctAnswer: In the generation of the righteous
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:5 says, 'God is in the generation of the righteous.'

questions.question: What has been shamed according to Psalms 14:6?
options: The counsel of the poor
The law of Moses
The temple services
The wisdom of the elders
questions.correctAnswer: The counsel of the poor
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:6 states, 'Ye have shamed the counsel of the poor.'

questions.question: Where does the Psalmist hope the salvation of Israel will come from, according to Psalms 14:7?
options: Zion
Babylon
Egypt
Jericho
questions.correctAnswer: Zion
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:7 says, 'Oh that the salvation of Israel were come out of Zion!'

questions.question: According to Psalms 14:1, what have the corrupt done?
options: Abominable works
Great miracles
Righteous deeds
Acts of kindness
questions.correctAnswer: Abominable works
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:1 states, 'They are corrupt, they have done abominable works.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 14:4, how do the workers of iniquity treat God's people?
options: They eat up my people as they eat bread
They protect my people
They teach my people
They pray for my people
questions.correctAnswer: They eat up my people as they eat bread
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:4 says, 'who eat up my people as they eat bread.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 14:2, what was God looking to see among the children of men?
options: If there were any that do understand and seek God
If they built temples
If they sang songs
If they offered sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: If there were any that do understand and seek God
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:2 states, 'to see if there were any that do understand, and seek God.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 14:3 says there is none that doeth good, no, not one.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:3 clearly states, 'there is none that doeth good, no, not one.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 14:5, the workers of iniquity have great confidence.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:5 says, 'There were they in great fear,' indicating the workers of iniquity fear because God is with the righteous.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 14:6 states that the LORD is the refuge of the poor.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:6 states, 'because the LORD is his refuge,' referring to the poor.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 14:7: '...when the LORD bringeth back the ______ of his people.'
options: captivity
joy
peace
strength
questions.correctAnswer: captivity
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:7 says, 'when the LORD bringeth back the captivity of his people.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 14:1: 'The fool hath said in his heart, ______.'
options: There is no God
God is good
The LORD is my shepherd
God will save us
questions.correctAnswer: There is no God
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:1 begins with, 'The fool hath said in his heart, There is no God.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 14 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 14 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with doubt about God's existence. Based on Psalms 14, what biblical truth would you share to encourage their faith?
options: The fool says in his heart there is no God, but God sees all and calls us to seek Him.
God does not care about those who doubt.
Faith does not require understanding.
Doubt is proof that God does not exist.
questions.correctAnswer: The fool says in his heart there is no God, but God sees all and calls us to seek Him.
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:1 teaches that denying God is foolish, and Psalms 14:2 shows that God looks to see who seeks Him. This encourages believers to seek God in faith despite doubts.

questions.question: How does Psalms 14 instruct us about integrity in our daily life and work?
options: All are corrupt and none do good, so integrity is rare and unnecessary.
Workers of iniquity lack knowledge and exploit others without calling on the Lord.
Only leaders need to be honest in their work.
Integrity is a personal choice unrelated to faith.
questions.correctAnswer: Workers of iniquity lack knowledge and exploit others without calling on the Lord.
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:4 highlights that those who do wrong exploit God’s people and do not seek the Lord, encouraging believers to maintain honesty and seek God in their work.

questions.question: A believer feels ashamed when others mock their faith. According to Psalms 14, what truth can help them persevere?
options: God is in the generation of the righteous and will protect them.
Shame means God has abandoned you.
Faith is only for the strong and unshakable.
You must stop believing to avoid shame.
questions.correctAnswer: God is in the generation of the righteous and will protect them.
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:5 assures believers that God is present with the righteous, giving them confidence despite shame or fear.

questions.question: How does Psalms 14 encourage believers to rely on God in times of trouble?
options: The LORD is the refuge of the poor, so we can trust Him for protection.
Troubles prove God has forsaken us.
Relying on God is optional in hardship.
Only wealth can protect from trouble.
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is the refuge of the poor, so we can trust Him for protection.
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:6 states that the LORD is the refuge of the poor, teaching believers to trust God’s protection in adversity.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 14, what should be our attitude towards those who do evil and do not seek God?
options: Recognize they have gone astray and pray for their repentance.
Ignore them completely.
Join them to avoid conflict.
Assume they are better off without God.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize they have gone astray and pray for their repentance.
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:3 describes that all have gone astray and none do good, encouraging believers to intercede and hope for their turning to God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 14 guide us in evangelism and sharing the Gospel?
options: Declare that fools deny God and call people to seek Him as the Lord watches over all.
Avoid talking about faith to prevent offense.
Only preach to those who already believe.
Focus on worldly success instead of spiritual matters.
questions.correctAnswer: Declare that fools deny God and call people to seek Him as the Lord watches over all.
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:1-2 shows the folly of denying God and that God watches over those who seek Him, motivating believers to share this truth.

questions.question: When facing personal trials, how does Psalms 14 suggest believers maintain hope?
options: Trust that the salvation of Israel will come and rejoice in God’s deliverance.
Give up hope and accept defeat.
Rely only on personal strength.
Wait passively without prayer.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that the salvation of Israel will come and rejoice in God’s deliverance.
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:7 expresses longing for salvation and rejoicing when God delivers, teaching believers to hope in God’s timing and faithfulness.

questions.question: What biblical principle about humility and contentment is taught in Psalms 14?
options: The poor who trust in the LORD are not to be shamed, as God is their refuge.
Only the rich are blessed by God.
Poverty is a sign of God’s displeasure.
Humility is irrelevant to God’s protection.
questions.correctAnswer: The poor who trust in the LORD are not to be shamed, as God is their refuge.
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:6 shows that the poor find refuge in God and should not be shamed, teaching humility and reliance on God rather than status.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 14, everyone has done good and there is no sin.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:3 clearly states that all have gone astray and none do good, emphasizing universal sinfulness.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 14 teaches that God actively watches over the children of men to see who seeks Him.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:2 states that the LORD looks down from heaven to see if anyone understands and seeks God.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with anger towards those who exploit others. Based on Psalms 14, how should they view such workers of iniquity?
options: They lack knowledge and do not call upon the LORD.
They are justified in their actions.
They are more faithful than others.
Their actions are beyond God's concern.
questions.correctAnswer: They lack knowledge and do not call upon the LORD.
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:4 describes workers of iniquity as ignorant and unrepentant, encouraging believers to recognize their spiritual blindness.

questions.question: How does Psalms 14 teach us about the importance of prayer and seeking God?
options: God looks to see who seeks Him and those who do not call upon Him are corrupt.
Prayer is unnecessary because God ignores people.
Seeking God is only for religious leaders.
People should rely on themselves rather than prayer.
questions.correctAnswer: God looks to see who seeks Him and those who do not call upon Him are corrupt.
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:2 and 14:4 teach that God observes those who seek Him and condemns those who do not call on Him, highlighting prayer’s importance.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 14 says, 'Oh that the salvation of Israel were come out of ____, when the LORD bringeth back the captivity of his people.'
options: Zion
Babylon
Jerusalem
Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Zion
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:7 expresses longing for salvation to come out of Zion, symbolizing God's deliverance.

questions.question: How does Psalms 14 guide a believer in dealing with shame from others about their faith?
options: Recognize that the LORD is the refuge of the poor and be confident in His protection.
Stop sharing your faith to avoid shame.
Seek revenge on those who shame you.
Ignore God and rely on yourself.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize that the LORD is the refuge of the poor and be confident in His protection.
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:6 teaches that the LORD is a refuge, encouraging believers to trust God rather than fear shame.

questions.question: What practical lesson about spiritual discipline can we learn from Psalms 14 regarding understanding and seeking God?
options: God looks to see if anyone understands and seeks Him, so we must cultivate understanding and seek Him continually.
Understanding is not important in faith.
Seeking God is only necessary occasionally.
God only seeks those who are perfect.
questions.correctAnswer: God looks to see if anyone understands and seeks Him, so we must cultivate understanding and seek Him continually.
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:2 emphasizes God's attention to those who seek and understand Him, encouraging daily spiritual discipline.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 14 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 14.

questions.question: In Psalms 14:1, the term 'fool' is used to describe one who denies God's existence. How does the Hebrew word for 'fool' (nabal) reflect the moral and spiritual state described?
options: It denotes one who is morally deficient and rejects divine wisdom
It simply means one who lacks intellectual capacity
It refers to a person who is socially outcast
It means someone who is ignorant of the law but not sinful
questions.correctAnswer: It denotes one who is morally deficient and rejects divine wisdom
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'nabal' used in Psalms 14:1 implies a moral deficiency and rejection of divine wisdom, not just intellectual ignorance.

questions.question: Psalms 14:2 mentions that the LORD looked down from heaven to see if there were any who understood and sought God. This divine observation parallels which New Testament teaching about God’s knowledge of the heart?
options: 1 Samuel 16:7, emphasizing God looks at the heart, not outward appearance
Matthew 7:21, emphasizing doing the Father’s will
John 3:16, emphasizing belief in the Son
Romans 3:23, emphasizing all have sinned
questions.correctAnswer: 1 Samuel 16:7, emphasizing God looks at the heart, not outward appearance
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:2's depiction of God looking from heaven to see understanding parallels 1 Samuel 16:7 where God judges by the heart rather than outward appearance.

questions.question: According to Psalms 14:3, what is the universal condition of humanity?
options: All have gone astray and become corrupt; no one does good
Some are righteous and some are wicked
The majority are righteous but some are corrupt
Only a few are truly faithful
questions.correctAnswer: All have gone astray and become corrupt; no one does good
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:3 states that all people have gone astray and become corrupt, emphasizing universal human sinfulness.

questions.question: The phrase 'eat up my people as they eat bread' in Psalms 14:4 is an example of what literary device?
options: Metaphor illustrating the ease and regularity of wickedness
Simile showing a comparison to a feast
Hyperbole exaggerating the destruction
Irony highlighting the weakness of the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor illustrating the ease and regularity of wickedness
questions.explanation: The phrase uses metaphor to depict how wicked people consume God's people as easily and regularly as eating bread.

questions.question: In Psalms 14:5, why were the workers of iniquity in great fear according to the text?
options: Because God is in the generation of the righteous
Because they feared punishment from the king
Because they were surrounded by enemies
Because they doubted their own strength
questions.correctAnswer: Because God is in the generation of the righteous
questions.explanation: The psalm explains that the workers of iniquity feared because God is present with the righteous generation, implying divine protection.

questions.question: Psalms 14:6 states that the counsel of the poor was shamed. This reflects what broader biblical theme about God's care for the marginalized?
options: God is the refuge of the poor and oppressed
The poor are often ignored by God
Councils of the poor are inherently flawed
Wealth is a sign of divine favor
questions.correctAnswer: God is the refuge of the poor and oppressed
questions.explanation: The verse highlights that despite shaming, the LORD remains the refuge for the poor, aligning with the biblical theme of God's special care for the marginalized.

questions.question: The longing expressed in Psalms 14:7 for salvation to come out of Zion foreshadows which major event in Israel’s history?
options: The return from Babylonian exile
The giving of the Law at Mount Sinai
The conquest of Canaan
The building of Solomon’s temple
questions.correctAnswer: The return from Babylonian exile
questions.explanation: The verse’s hope for salvation from Zion and restoration of captivity points forward to the return from Babylonian exile.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 14 declares that there is at least one person who does good and seeks God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:3 explicitly states that there is no one who does good, no, not one.

questions.question: How does the theme of corruption in Psalms 14 connect to the New Testament teaching in Romans 3:10-12?
options: Both passages affirm that all have turned away from God and no one does good
Romans emphasizes salvation by works, while Psalms emphasizes judgment
Romans focuses on Gentiles only, Psalms on Israelites
Psalms speaks of physical corruption, Romans of spiritual
questions.correctAnswer: Both passages affirm that all have turned away from God and no one does good
questions.explanation: Both Psalms 14:3 and Romans 3:10-12 affirm the universal human condition of sin and absence of good.

questions.question: The phrase 'God is in the generation of the righteous' (Psalms 14:5) suggests what about ancient Israelite understanding of divine presence?
options: God dwells among the community of the faithful
God is distant and uninvolved
God only appears in the temple
God is indifferent to human affairs
questions.correctAnswer: God dwells among the community of the faithful
questions.explanation: The phrase indicates that God is present within and protects those who are righteous, reflecting ancient Israelite belief in God’s immanence.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 14:1 says the fool hath said in his heart, 'There is no _____.'
options: God
Truth
Justice
Mercy
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states the fool’s denial: 'There is no God.'

questions.question: Which Old Testament book shares a similar poetic structure and theme about fools denying God as Psalms 14?
options: Proverbs
Ecclesiastes
Job
Isaiah
questions.correctAnswer: Proverbs
questions.explanation: Proverbs often contrasts the wise and the fool, including denials of God, paralleling Psalms 14's theme and poetic style.

questions.question: The 'captivity' mentioned in Psalms 14:7 refers to what specific historical or theological concept?
options: The exile of Israel to Babylon
The slavery in Egypt
The Assyrian conquest of Israel
The Roman occupation of Judea
questions.correctAnswer: The exile of Israel to Babylon
questions.explanation: The captivity alludes to the Babylonian exile, a key event in Israel’s history and theology.

questions.question: In Psalms 14, the repeated assertion 'there is none that doeth good' serves as an example of what Hebrew literary device?
options: Parallelism emphasizing universal sinfulness
Chiasm highlighting moral reversal
Allegory illustrating spiritual blindness
Metonymy representing societal corruption
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism emphasizing universal sinfulness
questions.explanation: The repetition creates a parallelism that underscores the universal nature of human sin described in the text.

questions.question: How does Psalms 14:6's statement 'because the LORD is his refuge' contrast with the behavior of the workers of iniquity in the chapter?
options: The righteous trust in God, while the wicked do not call upon the LORD
Both groups equally trust in God for protection
The wicked have a stronger refuge in God than the poor
The verse suggests the poor have no refuge
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous trust in God, while the wicked do not call upon the LORD
questions.explanation: The chapter contrasts the workers of iniquity who do not call on God with the poor who find refuge in the LORD.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 14 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 14 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 14:1, what is declared about the fool's belief in God?
options: The fool hath said in his heart, There is no God
The fool acknowledges God's existence but denies His power
The fool believes in many gods
The fool worships idols instead of God
questions.correctAnswer: The fool hath said in his heart, There is no God
questions.explanation: Psalms 14:1 explicitly states that the fool has said in his heart that there is no God, reflecting human denial of God's existence. This theme is consistent with Romans 1:20-22, Psalm 53:1, Ecclesiastes 7:20, and John 3:18 where unbelief is addressed.

questions.question: What does Psalms 14:2 reveal about God's attitude toward humanity?
options: The LORD looked down from heaven to see if any understood and sought God
God ignores the deeds of men
God is angry and punishes without mercy
God only cares for the righteous and ignores the rest
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD looked down from heaven to see if any understood and sought God
questions.explanation: Psalm 14:2 shows God's active observation of humanity, seeking those who truly seek Him. This aligns with Proverbs 15:3, Isaiah 66:1, Acts 17:27, and Hebrews 11:6 where God's attentiveness and desire for relationship with humans is emphasized.

questions.question: What is the universal condition of mankind according to Psalms 14:3?
options: All have gone astray and become corrupt; none does good, not even one
Some are righteous and some are sinners
Most do good, but some fall short
The majority seek God but often fail
questions.correctAnswer: All have gone astray and become corrupt; none does good, not even one
questions.explanation: Psalm 14:3 declares the universal sinfulness of mankind, stating that none does good, highlighting total depravity consistent with Romans 3:10-12, Ecclesiastes 7:20, Isaiah 53:6, and Jeremiah 17:9.

questions.question: In Psalms 14:4, what is said about the workers of iniquity and their knowledge?
options: They have no knowledge and consume God's people without calling on the LORD
They are wise and seek God's counsel
They fear God and repent
They are ignorant but call upon the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: They have no knowledge and consume God's people without calling on the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalm 14:4 highlights the ignorance of evildoers who exploit God's people yet fail to call on the LORD, paralleling Jeremiah 4:22, Hosea 4:6, Proverbs 1:7, and Romans 1:28 on the consequences of rejecting God's knowledge.

questions.question: According to Psalms 14:5, why were the workers of iniquity in great fear?
options: Because God is in the generation of the righteous
Because of impending natural disasters
Because they feared other nations
Because they feared their own consciences
questions.correctAnswer: Because God is in the generation of the righteous
questions.explanation: Psalm 14:5 states that evildoers feared because God is among the righteous, affirming God's protective presence. This is supported by Isaiah 8:13, Psalm 34:7, Proverbs 29:25, and Hebrews 12:29 on reverence and fear of God.

questions.question: Who is described as having their counsel shamed in Psalms 14:6, and why?
options: The poor, because the LORD is his refuge
The rich, because they trust in wealth
The wicked, because they reject God
The kings, because of their arrogance
questions.correctAnswer: The poor, because the LORD is his refuge
questions.explanation: Psalm 14:6 notes how the counsel of the poor is shamed despite the LORD being their refuge, emphasizing God's care for the humble. This is echoed in Proverbs 14:31, Matthew 5:3, Psalm 9:9, and Isaiah 25:4 regarding God's protection of the poor and oppressed.

questions.question: What eschatological hope is expressed in Psalms 14:7?
options: The salvation of Israel coming out of Zion and the LORD bringing back the captivity
The destruction of Israel's enemies
The eternal reign of the king of Egypt
The end of all nations
questions.correctAnswer: The salvation of Israel coming out of Zion and the LORD bringing back the captivity
questions.explanation: Psalm 14:7 expresses hope for salvation from Zion and restoration of Israel, a messianic and eschatological theme consistent with Isaiah 59:20, Jeremiah 30:3, Luke 1:69, and Romans 11:26 about God's redemptive plan for Israel.

questions.question: Which attribute of God is most clearly demonstrated by His looking down from heaven in Psalms 14:2?
options: Omniscience and providence
Immutability
Omnipotence
Transcendence only
questions.correctAnswer: Omniscience and providence
questions.explanation: God's looking down from heaven to see if humans seek Him shows His omniscience and providential care, aligned with Psalm 33:13-15, Proverbs 5:21, Matthew 10:29-30, and Hebrews 4:13 describing God's all-knowing and sovereign oversight.

questions.question: What theological doctrine is underscored by the repeated assertion in Psalms 14:1 and 14:3 that 'there is none that doeth good'?
options: Total depravity of mankind
Universal salvation
Predestination
Moral neutrality of humanity
questions.correctAnswer: Total depravity of mankind
questions.explanation: The declaration that no one does good highlights mankind's total depravity, a key biblical doctrine found also in Romans 3:10-18, Jeremiah 17:9, Ecclesiastes 7:20, and Ephesians 2:1-3 about humanity's sinful nature apart from God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 14:4's description of workers of iniquity 'eating up my people as they eat bread' relate to biblical themes of sin?
options: It illustrates exploitation and oppression of God's people
It refers to literal cannibalism
It symbolizes sharing meals in fellowship
It indicates the workers' humility
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates exploitation and oppression of God's people
questions.explanation: The metaphor in Psalm 14:4 depicts evildoers oppressing the people of God, consistent with Exodus 1:14, Isaiah 3:14, Micah 2:1-2, and James 5:4 which condemn exploitation and injustice.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'God is in the generation of the righteous' in Psalms 14:5 imply about God's presence?
options: God dwells among and supports the righteous community
God is absent from the righteous
God only judges the righteous
God is indifferent to human generations
questions.correctAnswer: God dwells among and supports the righteous community
questions.explanation: Psalm 14:5 emphasizes God's intimate presence with the righteous, paralleling Exodus 29:45, Psalm 46:5, Matthew 18:20, and 1 Corinthians 3:16 where God's dwelling with His people is affirmed.

questions.question: What does Psalms 14:6 teach about the LORD's role for the poor?
options: The LORD is the refuge of the poor
The LORD ignores the poor
The LORD punishes the poor
The LORD favors the rich over the poor
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is the refuge of the poor
questions.explanation: Psalm 14:6 declares the LORD as refuge for the poor, affirming God's protection and care, also seen in Psalm 9:9, Psalm 34:18, Isaiah 25:4, and Luke 4:18 about God's concern for the vulnerable.

questions.question: What is the ultimate reason for Israel's rejoicing in Psalms 14:7?
options: The LORD bringing back the captivity of His people
The defeat of their enemies by human armies
The prosperity of Israel's kings
The completion of the temple construction
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD bringing back the captivity of His people
questions.explanation: Psalm 14:7 associates Israel's joy with God's restoration of His people from captivity, consistent with Isaiah 44:22-23, Jeremiah 31:7, Zechariah 10:7, and Luke 1:68-69 highlighting God's redemptive work.

questions.question: How does Psalms 14 contribute to the doctrine of salvation history?
options: By expressing hope for deliverance from Zion and restoration of Israel
By denying any future restoration
By focusing solely on present human efforts
By emphasizing worldly powers over God
questions.correctAnswer: By expressing hope for deliverance from Zion and restoration of Israel
questions.explanation: Psalm 14:7's eschatological hope reflects the biblical narrative of God's salvation history, paralleled in Isaiah 2:3, Jeremiah 23:5-6, Romans 11:26, and Revelation 21:2 concerning God's plan to restore His people eternally.

questions.question: What does Psalms 14 teach about the relationship between sin and knowledge of God?
options: Workers of iniquity have no knowledge and do not call upon the LORD
Sin increases knowledge of God
All sinners have some knowledge of God
Knowledge of God causes sin
questions.correctAnswer: Workers of iniquity have no knowledge and do not call upon the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalm 14:4 highlights that evildoers lack true knowledge of God and fail to call on Him, reflecting themes in Hosea 4:6, Jeremiah 4:22, Romans 1:21, and 1 Corinthians 1:18 about ignorance leading to sin.
